Wecome @nicomignoni!

Generally in the julia space, when people hear "vectorization", they're thinking of [SIMD vectorization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Single_instruction,_multiple_data). I'll admit when I saw this go up for registration, my first thought was that it was related to that, and then I thought "Oh, maybe this is vectorization in the sense used by Numpy / Matlab people for what we call 'broadcast". It took me a while to realize this was for stacking vectors together and assigning each component a name for some reason. 

Definitely not a 'hard requirement', but I'd perhaps recommend choosing another name that is perhaps a bit clearer to readers what it's for. I think even something like 
* NamedVecCat
* ComponentVecCat

could make it a significantly clearer, since `vec` is already the julia function for making a linear vector out of  `N` dimensional structures, and `cat` is the term we use for con**cat**enation.

_____

In terms of functionality, I'll also point out that this package has **significant** overlap with the [ComponentArrays.jl](https://github.com/SciML/ComponentArrays.jl) package. Here's how you'd do the [examples from the README](https://nicomignoni.github.io/NamedVectorizations.jl/dev/) with ComponentArrays using essentially identical syntax:
```julia
julia> using ComponentArrays

julia> begin
           A = [4 5; 2 1]
           b = [9; -2]
           c = 7

           ca = ComponentArray(A=A, b=b, c=c)
       end
ComponentVector{Int64}(A = [4 5; 2 1], b = [9, -2], c = 7)
```
```julia
julia> ca.A
2×2 reshape(view(::Vector{Int64}, 1:4), 2, 2) with eltype Int64:
 4  5
 2  1

julia> ca.b
2-element view(::Vector{Int64}, 5:6) with eltype Int64:
  9
 -2

julia> ca.c
7
```
```julia
julia> Vector(ca)
7-element Vector{Int64}:
  4
  2
  5
  1
  9
 -2
  7
```
```julia
julia> getaxes(ca)
(Axis(A = ViewAxis(1:4, ShapedAxis((2, 2))), b = ViewAxis(5:6, Shaped1DAxis((2,))), c = 7),)
```

Is there anything you can do with this package that one can't do in ComponentArrays.jl or can't be easily added to ComponentArrays.jl with a PR? There's generally no problem with having multiple packages with significant overlap, but when there is, it's important to clarify why a new package is needed in this space and in what circumstances it should be used over the older pre-existing packages. 

So if there is something that makes this shine relative to ComponentArrays, I would ask you to add something about that to your README / docs.

Hello @MasonProtter and thank you for the quick review!

I apologize for the documentation being extremely terse, `NamedVectorization.jl` is a small package that I need for a larger project about variational inequalities (VIs), but I find it useful as standalone for some of my optimization and mathematical modelling needs. 

In the optimization / VIs / convex analysis areas, [this](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vectorization_(mathematics)) is what people means by *vectorization*, although I agree that it might be confused with different but homonymous concepts. What about `NamedVec`? It is available on the registry, and it is maybe a bit easier to pronounce than `NamedVecCat` :) . 

As for the overlap with `ComponentArrays`, the main difference is that `NamedVectorizations` tries to preserve the `NV` structure "as much as possible" falling back to an `Array` only when the `layout` changes or becomes ambiguous. `ComponentArrays` seems to do it for most cases: going back to the quickstart example, we have
```julia
using NamedVectorizations, ComponentArrays

A = [4 5; 2 1]
b = [9; -2]
c = 7

ca = ComponentArray(A=A, b=b, c=c)
nv = NV(A=A, b=b, c=c)
```
The `ComponentArray` structure is preserved for scalar broadcasting and `vcat` (when the  `layout` is different)
```julia
julia> 2ca
ComponentVector{Int64}(A = [4 5; 2 1], b = [9, -2], c = 7)

julia> ca .+ 1
ComponentVector{Int64}(A = [5 6; 3 2], b = [10, -1], c = 8)

julia> ca2 = ComponentArray(d=[2 3; 0 -5], e=3, f=[1, 3]);
julia> vcat(ca, ca2) 
ComponentVector{Int64}(A = [4 5; 2 1], b = [9, -2], c = 7, d = [2 3; 0 -5], e = 3, f = [1, 3])
```

however, in case of, e.g., matrix multiplication, this is not the case anymore
```julia
M = rand(7, 7)

julia> M * ca
7-element Vector{Float64}:
 20.544664037807415
 17.19027701311383
  9.691286477849847
 16.50403192545688
 19.77931411723072
  8.254524946757265
 12.704243794353575
```
With an `NV`, instead, the vectorized structure is preserved, as the `layout` remains unaltered

```julia
julia> M * nv
7-element NV{Float64} with layout: 
├ A: Matrix 2x2, [1-4]
├ b: 2-element Vector, [5-6]
└ c: Number, [7]:
 20.544664037807415
 17.19027701311383
  9.691286477849847
 16.50403192545688
 19.77931411723072
  8.254524946757265
 12.704243794353575
```
If we were to multiply by a rectangular matrix, the result would fall back to a `Vector`, as the `layout` would be altered in length
```julia
M = rand(5, 7)

julia> M * nv
5-element Vector{Float64}:
 13.32959886623553
 16.728508642760282
 18.20024574308967
 12.139114738780965
 15.120611176597235
```
This is the only difference (as far as I can tell for now) that makes `NamedVectorizations` preferable for me over `ComponentArray`, although I will try to open a PR on the matter before continuing developing `NamedVectorizations` and re-applying for registering. There is also a future line of work for making `NV` preservable under `ChainRules`; if I build up enough differences with `ComponentArray`, I will try to register `NamedVectorizations` (or `NamedVecCat`) again.

FWIW, I think that in general it's not a great idea for the return type of `*` to depend on whether or not the matrix is square. That will cause a type instability because it's not knowable at the type level if a matrix is square.

One way around this with ComponentArrays would be:
```julia
julia> ComponentArray(M * ca, getaxes(ca))
ComponentVector{Float64}(A = [14.567553140727663 13.913403407962338; 22.48457510149916 12.000061249958662], b = [22.698551310711647, 20.91248345463166], c = 9.1369921469342)
```

Also no need to apologize for the terse documentation, I think for a small package like this with a small API, that's a more or less normal amount of documentation. It's always nice to see new people registering packages and exploring concepts!

> What about NamedVec? It is available on the registry, and it is maybe a bit easier to pronounce than NamedVecCat :) .

Yeah that's definitely a possibility, and was actually originally going to be my suggestion. I decided to suggest `NamedVecCat` because it seemed less ambiguous with packages like NamedDims.jl or whatever, but I think it's also not a big deal, and NamedVec is probably fine. 

Best of luck with your development!
